title.narrative: Substance abuse and human trafficking prevention project

description.narrative: The goal of the project is to contribute toward increasing the capacity of civil society in order to strengthen societal participation to fulfil the rights of youth (especially girls and women) through the prevention of drug abuse and human trafficking in Burundi. The project promotes improved fulfillment of the right to lessen the capacity gap to pursue a healthy life and better living standards for drug/alcohol and human trafficking youth victims in Makamba Bujumbura Ruyigi Muyinga and Cibitoke provinces. Aims to:- Increased awareness among youth parents school headmasters teachers and community leaders in 5 target regions on the prevention of drugs/alcohol and human trafficking.- Strengthened capacity of the partner organization (CEPBU) to operate as a st rong civil society actor to advocate for the rights of youth and children in Burundi.- Increased capacity of resilience in youth against drug abuse and human trafficking in Burundi.This is a joint project (between FS Global/FSPM Samaria Group and CEPBU tha t addresses the prevention management schemes of drug abuse and human trafficking issues in Burundi. The key development areas which the project aims to find solutions for is the abuse of drugs or prohibited alcohol and the human trafficking of youth in Bu rundi leading to forced migration and the depletion of the capacity of youth to work with development activities. The long-term objective is to deter youth from abusing drugs prevent human trafficking and to increase knowledge regarding these issues within the target communities. Among the rights holders to be targeted are 240 youth from households in five provinces 550 participants in training events national administrations children and young students of local schools as well as their teachers and headmas ters. Also local communities at a large scale with an estimated population of 160290 people will benefit from an increased awareness on the issues of drug abuse and human trafficking. Another important group of beneficiaries included the 1.600.000 people w ho will receive information through various channels to increase awareness such as through CEPBUs Radio Ubutumwa bwAmahoro.
